scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Information
scopecontent.p: This collection consists of the correspondence and legal & financial papers of the Preston family of Abingdon, Virginia, and Columbia, South Carolina, twenty-two items, 1789-1845. The legal and financial papers, 1789-1830, pertain to Francis Preston, Robert Preston, William C. Preston, Robert R. Preston, and William R. Preston & the heirs of Francis Preston and include a receipt, an account of the estate of William Preston, an indenture, an agreement, an account with Shaw, Tiffany & Company, and a power of attorney.

Most of the correspondence is addressed to General Francis Preston, Abingdon, Virginia, and is chiefly concerned with business and legal matters, including advice about purchasing lands belonging to the estate of William King (1820 Mar 27); financial difficulties of his brother J[ohn?] Preston (1821 Nov 19); and an offer to help Francis Preston sell his lands in [Kentucky?] (1826 Jan 22); permission to use the name of George C. Light to inquire about Preston's Ohio lands from General Thomas Gatch of the Ohio Legislature (1826 Nov 28); a possible suit against Mr. Vance's heirs (1827 Oct 30); the status of several legal suits in the courts and the purchase of a land tract in Louisville, Kentucky (1831 Apr 16); and information about shipments of salt and plaster by William King & Company and an inquiry about whether Preston has a black woman, aged eighteen to twenty-one, for sale (1834 Apr 19); and a suit on behalf of E. Henry concerning a legacy in the will of Patrick Henry left to Edmond Henry (1844 Jan 13). Other topics include: request for information about difficulties at the Abingdon Lodge No. 48 (1809 Oct 7); a reference to the debate over the admission of slaves into Missouri (1820 Jan 23); an inquiry about a slave (1834 Apr 19); invitations to stay with two brothers in Macon, Georgia, during the Harrison Convention (1840 Aug 5 & 7); and social and family news (1845 Feb 8).
